member.name: T:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula
member.summary: Financial Formula Name enumeration

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.AccumulationDistribution
member.summary: The accumulation distribution formula is an improved On Balance Volume indicator. This indicator uses a relationship between volume and prices to estimate the strength of price movements, and if volume is increased there is a high probability that prices will go up.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.AverageTrueRange
member.summary: The Average True Range is an indicator that measures commitment and compares the range between the High, Low and Close prices. This indicator was developed by J. Welles Wilder.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.BollingerBands
member.summary: Bollinger Bands are indicators that are plotted at standard deviation levels above and below a simple moving average. Since standard deviation is a measure of volatility, a large standard deviation indicates a volatile market, while a smaller standard deviation indicates a calmer market. Bollinger Bands are a good way to compare volatility and relative price levels over a period of time.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.ChaikinOscillator
member.summary: The Chaikin Oscillator indicator is the difference between a 3-day exponential moving average and a 10-day exponential moving average applied to the Accumulation Distribution. Using the Chaikin Oscillator it is possible to monitor volume flow for a market. The Chaikin Oscillator should be used together with the price envelope.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.CommodityChannelIndex
member.summary: The Commodity Channel Index compares prices with their moving averages. If the Commodity channel index is high it means that a price is higher than its moving average, which is an indicator that security is overbought. If the Commodity channel index is low it means that a price is lower than its moving average, which is an indicator that security is oversold.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.DetrendedPriceOscillator
member.summary: The Detrended Price Oscillator attempts to remove trend from prices. By comparing the closing price or any other price with it's moving average, the Detrended Price Oscillator eliminates cycles that are longer than the moving average.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.EaseOfMovement
member.summary: Ease of Movement deals with the relationship between volume and price change, and uses volume to indicate how strong a trend is for prices. Ease of Movement was developed by Richard W Arms.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.Envelopes
member.summary: Envelopes are plotted above and below a moving average using a specified percentage as the shift. The envelopes indicator is used to create signals for buying and selling, and the percentage to be used for calculating the envelopes is specified by the user. This percentage should depend on the volatility of the market (the higher the market volatility, the higher the percentage should be).

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.ExponentialMovingAverage
member.summary: An Exponential Moving Average is an average of data calculated over a period of time where the most recent days have more weight. The exponential moving average can be used with any price: Hi, Low, Open and Close, or it could be applied to other indicators. An Exponential Moving average smooths a data series, which is very important in a volatile market.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.Forecasting
member.summary: The Time Series analysis has two main goals: Identifying the nature of a sequence of observations and predicting future values using historical observations (forecasting). In time series analysis it is assumed that the data consist of a systematic pattern and random noise which usually makes the pattern difficult to identify. Most time series analysis techniques uses filtering to remove noise.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.MACD
member.summary: The MACD (Moving Average Convergence/Divergence) indicator compares two moving averages of prices. The MACD is used with a 9-day Exponential Moving average as a signal, which indicates buying and selling moments. This indicator was developed by Gerald Appel.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.MassIndex
member.summary: The Mass Index is used to predict trend reversal by comparing the difference and range between High and Low prices. If the Mass Index increases the range between High and low increases. If the Mass Index decreases the range between High and Low decreases.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.MedianPrice
member.summary: Median prices are mid-point values of daily prices and can be used as a filter for trend indicators. They are also used as a daily average price which is very useful if we want a simpler "view" of prices.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.MoneyFlow
member.summary: The money flow indicator compares upward changes and downward changes of volume-weighted typical prices. This indicator is similar to the relative strength index, the difference being the volume-weighted prices. This indicator can be used to identify market tops and bottoms.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.NegativeVolumeIndex
member.summary: The Negative Volume Index should be used together with the Positive Volume index, and the Negative Volume Index only changes if the volume decreases from the previous day.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.OnBalanceVolume
member.summary: The On Balance Volume is one of the first volume indicators that measures positive and negative volume flow. Volume is added if the closing price increases and subtracted if the closing price decreases. On Balance Volume wass developed by Joseph Granville.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.Performance
member.summary: The Performance indicator compares a current Close (or any other price) with the first Close value (from the first time period ). This indicator shows the degree of a change in a price.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.PositiveVolumeIndex
member.summary: The Positive Volume Index should be used together with the Negative Volume index. The Positive volume index only changes if the volume decreases from the previous day.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.PriceVolumeTrend
member.summary: The Price Volume Trend is a cumulative volume total that is calculated using relative changes of the Close price, and should be used with other indicators.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.RateOfChange
member.summary: The Rate of Change indicator is very similar to the Performance indicator, where the Performance indicator compares the first price with current price while the Rate of Change compares a specified Close price with the current price. This formula is used for both prices and volume.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.RelativeStrengthIndex
member.summary: The Relative Strength Index is a momentum oscillator that compares upward movements of the Close price with downward movements, and results in values that range from 0 to 100. The Relative Strength index was developed by J. Welles Wilder.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.MovingAverage
member.summary: A Simple Moving Average is an average of data calculated over a period of time. The moving average is the most popular price indicator used in technical analyses, and can be used with any price (e.g.Hi, Low, Open and Close) or it can be applied to other indicators. A moving average smooths a data series, which is very important in a volatile market. Also, trends are easier to spot using a moving average.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.StandardDeviation
member.summary: Standard deviation is used to indicate volatility, and measures the difference between values (e.g. Closing Price) and their moving average. The larger the difference the higher the standard deviation and volatility. The smaller the difference the lower the standard deviation and volatility.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.StochasticIndicator
member.summary: When a trend is upward there is a tendency that the close price will be very close to that day's high. During a downward trending market there is a tendency that the close price is closer to the low price. The Stochastic Indicator helps to find trend reversal by searching for a period when: the close prices are close to low prices in an upward trending market; or close prices are close to high prices in a downward trending market. This formula has two output values: %K - Simple Stochastic Indicator and %D - Smoothed Stochastic Indicator (Moving Average of %K).

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.TriangularMovingAverage
member.summary: A Triangular Moving Average is an average of data calculated over a period of time where the middle portion of data has more weight. The Triangular Moving Average can be used with any price (Hi, Low, Open, Close) or it can be applied to other indicators. The Triangular Moving Average smooths a data series, which is very important in a volatile market.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.TRIX
member.summary: The TRIX is based on a triple moving average of the Closing Price, and its purpose is to eliminate short cycles. This indicator keeps the Close price in trends that are shorter than the specified period.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.TypicalPrice
member.summary: Typical price is the average value of daily prices, and can be used as a filter for trend indicators. It is also used as a daily average price which is very useful if we want a simpler view of prices.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.VolatilityChaikins
member.summary: The Volatility Chaikins indicator measures the difference between High and Low prices, and is used to indicate tops or bottoms of the market. This formula was developed by Marc Chaikin.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.VolumeOscillator
member.summary: The Volume oscillator attempts to identify trends in volume by comparing two moving averages; one with a short period and another with a longer period.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.WeightedClose
member.summary: The Weighted Close formula calculates the average value of daily prices. The only difference between Typical Price and the Weighted Close is that the closing price has extra weight, and is considered the most important price. The Weighted Close can be used as a filter for trend indicators, and can also be used as a daily average price (very useful if we want a simpler view of prices).

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.WeightedMovingAverage
member.summary: A Weighted Moving Average is an average of data calculated over a period of time, where greater weight is attached to the most recent data. The Weighted Moving Average can be used with any price (Hi, Low, Open, Close) or it can be applied to other indicators. The Weighted Moving Average smooths a data series, which is important in a volatile market. Weighting is calculated from a sum of days.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FinancialFormula.WilliamsR
member.summary: William's %R is a momentum indicator, and is used to measure overbought and oversold levels. This indicator is very similar to the Stochastic %K indicator, except that Williams %R is always a negative value between 0 and -100. This indicator was developed by Larry Williams.

member.name: T:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.ChartGraphics
member.summary: ChartGraphics class provides all chart drawing capabilities. It contains methods for drawing 2D primitives and also exposes all ChartGraphics3D class methods for 3D shapes. Only this class should be used for any drawing in the chart.

member.name: T:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.ChartGraphics3D
member.summary: ChartGraphics3D class is 3D chart rendering engine. All chart 3D shapes are drawn in specific order so that correct Z order of all shapes is achieved. 3D graphics engine do not support shapes intersection. 3D shapes are transformed into one or more 2D shapes and then drawn with 2D chart graphics engine.

member.name: T:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.LegendCellColumn
member.summary: The LegendCellColumn class represents a cell column in a legend, used to extend the functionality of the default legend. It contains visual appearance properties, legend header settings and also determine how and in which order cells are formed for each of the legend items.

member.name: T:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.LegendCell
member.summary: LegendCell class represents a single cell in the chart legend. Legend contains several legend items, each item contains several cells which form vertical columns. This class provide properties which determine content of the cell and its visual appearance. It also contains method which determine the size of the cell and draw cell in the chart.

member.name: P:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Legend.TextWrapThreshold
member.summary: Defines preferred number of characters in the legend text after which it will be wrapped.
member.remarks: When legend text exceeds the value defined in the TextWrapThreshold property it will be automatically wrapped on the next whitespace. Text will not be wrapped if there is no whitespace characters in the text. Set this property to zero to disable the feature.

member.name: P:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Legend.Reversed
member.summary: Indicates that legend items are shown in the reversed order. This property only affects legend items automatically added for the chart series and has no effect on custom legend items.
member.remarks: When the Reversed property is set to Auto, the legend will automatically be reversed if StackedColumn, StackedColumn100, StackedArea or StackedArea100 chart types are used.

member.name: T:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.ChartTypes.ChartTypeRegistry
member.summary:
ChartTypeRegistry class is a repository for all standard and custom chart types. In order for the chart control to display the chart type, it first must be registered using unique name and IChartType derived class which provides the description of the chart type and also responsible for all drawing and hit testing.
ChartTypeRegistry can be used by user for custom chart type registering and can be retrieved using Chart.GetService(typeof(ChartTypeRegistry)) method.

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Chart.DataBindTable(System.Collections.IEnumerable,System.String)
member.summary: Automatically creates and binds series to specified data table. Each column of the table becomes a Y value in a separate series. Series X value field may also be provided.
member.param: Name of the field for series X values.

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Chart.DataBindTable(System.Collections.IEnumerable)
member.summary: Automatically creates and binds series to specified data table. Each column of the table becomes a Y value in a separate series.

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Chart.DataBindCrossTab(System.Collections.IEnumerable,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Data bind chart to the table. Series will be automatically added to the chart depending ont yhe number of unique values in the seriesGroupByField column of the data source. Data source can be the Ole(SQL)DataReader, DataView, DataSet, DataTable or DataRow.
member.param: Name of the field used to group data into series.
Name of the field for X values.
Comma separated name(s) of the field(s) for Y value(s).
Other point properties binding rule in format: PointProperty=Field[{Format}] [,PointProperty=Field[{Format}]]. For example: "Tooltip=Price{C1},Href=WebSiteName".

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Chart.DataBindCrossTab(System.Collections.IEnumerable,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,Dundas.Charting.WinControl.PointsSortOrder)
member.summary: Data bind chart to the table. Series will be automatically added to the chart depending ont yhe number of unique values in the seriesGroupByField column of the data source. Data source can be the Ole(SQL)DataReader, DataView, DataSet, DataTable or DataRow.
member.param: Name of the field used to group data into series.
Name of the field for X values.
Comma separated name(s) of the field(s) for Y value(s).
Other point properties binding rule in format: PointProperty=Field[{Format}] [,PointProperty=Field[{Format}]]. For example: "Tooltip=Price{C1},Href=WebSiteName".
Series will be sorted by group field values in specified order.

member.name: T:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Command
member.summary:
Commands are the basis for interactions with user-interface elements.
Each command contains a chart functionality that developers can utilize to build their own custom toolbar and/or context menu.
The type of command is determined by property. The Command has and can be executed by method.
member.remarks:
Commands are either Standart and Used-Defined. The Standart Commands are provided for common actions required by end-user while User-Defined Commands afford the extension of existing commands or creating unique behavior.
Some commands contains other commands and this determines their special behavior - they are group conainers and apear in the context menu as menu item with subitems or pulldown buttons in toolbar.
The command contans visual attributes such as , and which determines the appereance of the command in the toolbar and the context menu.

member.summary: Determines the toggle behavior in the toolbar and context menu.

member.remarks:
The possible values are:
ToggleStyleDescriptions
NoneCommand behaves like regular button or menu item.

member.name: P:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Command.UseLastSubCommand
member.summary: Determines if the last sub-command executed will be set as the default behavior.
member.value: True to use last executed command, otherwize false. Default is true
member.remarks: The UseLastSubCommand property allows the user quickly call the toolbar command more than once if nesessary. When UseLastSubCommand is set to True the button will display last executed sub-command and execute it when button is pressed.

member.name: P:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Command.SupportedElements
member.summary: Gets or sets the supported elements of the command.
member.value: The set which represents supported chart elements of this .
member.remarks: The SupportedElements reflects in the context menu deployment. On right mouse click the selected chart element is inspected and compared with value to determine which to be displayed. Each has predefined set of which can be accepted and handled by this . The SupportedElements property can limit default predefined set but cannot expand it.

member.name: P:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Command.PopupStyle

The property is used to determine how to display group of ( sub-commands). The possible values are:
CommandPopupStyleDescriptions
MenuThe UI will display the command group as menu items, with text and adjacent icon.
TableThe UI will display the command group as table of icons.

member.name: T:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Utilities.CustomAttributeInfo
member.summary:
CustomAttributeInfo class stores information about single custom attribute. It includes Name, Description, Default Value, any restrictions and the conditions when it can be used.
Most of the custom attribute can only be used when specific chart type is selected. Some of the attributes only work in 2D or 3D mode and some can be applied to the whole series or data points only.

member.summary:
RangeChart class provides 2D/3D drawing and hit testing functionality for the Range and SplineRange charts. The only difference of the SplineRange chart is the default tension of the line.
SplineChart base class provides most of the functionality like drawing lines, labels and markers.

Darkenning scale for top surface. 0 - None.
Darkenning scale for bottom surface. 0 - None.
Position where the third point is actually located or float.NaN if same as in "firstPoint".
Position where the fourth point is actually located or float.NaN if same as in "secondPoint".

member.name: P:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.AnnotationGroup.ClipToChartArea
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the chart area the annotation is clipped to.
member.value: A string that represents the name of an existing chart area.
member.remarks:
If a chart area name is specified the annotation will only be drawn inside the plotting area of that chart area. All parts of the annotation outside of the plotting area will be clipped.
To disable chart area clipping set this property to "NotSet", or an empty string.

member.name: P:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.AnnotationGroup.SizeAlwaysRelative
member.summary: Gets or sets a flag that specifies whether the annotation size is always defined in relative chart coordinates.
member.value: True if this annotation's and are always in chart relative coordinates, false otherwise.
member.remarks: An annotation's width and height may be set in chart relative or axes coordinates. By default relative chart coordinates are used. To use axes coordinates for size set this property to false and either anchor the annotation to a data point or set the or properties.

member.name: T:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Statistics
member.summary: Statistics class provides helper methods for statisctical calculations. Actual calculations are made in the FormulaData class and the Statistics class provide a simplified API which automatically prepares parameters and deals with input and output series.

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Statistics.#ctor(Dundas.Charting.WinControl.FormulaData)
member.summary: Constructor

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Statistics.ZTest(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: The z-test generates a standard score for x with respect to the data set, array, and returns the two-tailed probability for the normal distribution. You can use this function to assess the likelihood that a particular observation is drawn from a particular population.
member.returns: Returns Result class from T Test

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Statistics.TTestUnEqualVariances(System.Double,System.Double,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: This analysis tool and its formulas perform a two-sample student's t-test. This t-test form assumes that the variances of both ranges of data are unequal; it is referred to as a heteroscedastic t-test. You can use a t-test to determine whether two sample means are equal. Use this test when the groups under study are distinct. Use a paired test when there is one group before and after a treatment.
member.returns: Returns Result class from T Test

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Statistics.TTestEqualVariances(System.Double,System.Double,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Two-Sample Assuming Equal Variances - This analysis tool performs a two-sample student's t-test. This t-test form assumes that the means of both data sets are equal; it is referred to as a homoscedastic t-test. You can use t-tests to determine whether two sample means are equal.
member.returns: Returns Result class from T Test

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Statistics.TTestPaired(System.Double,System.Double,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: This analysis tool and its formula perform a paired two-sample student's t-test to determine whether a sample's means are distinct. This t-test form does not assume that the variances of both populations are equal. You can use a paired test when there is a natural pairing of observations in the samples, such as when a sample group is tested twice — before and after an experiment.
member.returns: Returns Result class from T Test

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Statistics.RemoveEmptyPoints(System.String)
member.summary: Removes empty points from series.

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Statistics.FTest(System.Double,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: This analysis tool performs a two-sample F-test to compare two population variances. For example, you can use an F-test to determine whether the time scores in a swimming meet have a difference in variance for samples from two teams.
member.returns: Returns Result class from F Test

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Statistics.Anova(System.Double,System.String)
member.summary: This analysis tool performs simple analysis of variance (anova) to test the hypothesis that means from two or more samples are equal (drawn from populations with the same mean). This technique expands on the tests for two means, such as the t-test.
member.returns: Returns Result class from Anova Test

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Statistics.NormalDistribution(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the normal cumulative distribution for the specified mean and standard deviation. This function has a very wide range of applications in statistics, including hypothesis testing.
member.returns: Returns value from standard normal cumulative distribution function.

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Statistics.InverseNormalDistribution(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the inverse of the normal cumulative distribution for the specified mean and standard deviation.
member.returns: Returns value from inverse standard normal cumulative distribution function.

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Statistics.FDistribution(System.Double,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: /// Returns the F probability distribution. You can use this function to determine whether two data sets have different degrees of diversity. For example, you can examine test scores given to men and women entering high school and determine if the variability in the females is different from that found in the males.
member.returns: Returns value from cumulative F distribution function.

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Statistics.InverseFDistribution(System.Double,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the inverse of the F probability distribution. If p = FDIST(x,...), then FINV(p,...) = x. The F distribution can be used in an F-test that compares the degree of variability in two data sets. For example, you can analyze income distributions in the United States and Canada to determine whether the two countries have a similar degree of diversity.
member.returns: Returns value from inverse F distribution function.

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Statistics.TDistribution(System.Double,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns the Percentage Points (probability) for the Student t-distribution where a numeric value (x) is a calculated value of t for which the Percentage Points are to be computed. The t-distribution is used in the hypothesis testing of small sample data sets. Use this function in place of a table of critical values for the t-distribution.

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Statistics.InverseTDistribution(System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the t-value of the Student's t-distribution as a function of the probability and the degrees of freedom.

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Statistics.Covariance(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: This analysis tool and its formula return the average of the product of deviations of data points from their respective means. Covariance is a measure of the relationship between two ranges of data. You can use the Covariance tool to determine whether two ranges of data move together — that is, whether large values of one set are associated with large values of the other (positive covariance), whether small values of one set are associated with large values of the other (negative covariance), or whether values in both sets are unrelated (covariance near zero).

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Statistics.Correlation(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: This analysis tool and its formulas measure the relationship between two data sets that are scaled to be independent of the unit of measurement. The population correlation calculation returns the covariance of two data sets divided by the product of their standard deviations. You can use the Correlation tool to determine whether two ranges of data move together — that is, whether large values of one set are associated with large values of the other (positive correlation), whether small values of one set are associated with large values of the other (negative correlation), or whether values in both sets are unrelated (correlation near zero).

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Statistics.Mean(System.String)
member.summary: /// Returns the average (arithmetic mean) of the arguments.

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Statistics.Median(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the median of the given numbers. The median is the number in the middle of a set of numbers; that is, half the numbers have values that are greater than the median, and half have values that are less.

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Statistics.Variance(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Estimates variance based on a sample.
member.param: Boolen variable which determine if variance is used from sample.

member.summary: Moves a cool bar to the end of the drawing order.
member.remarks: This causes the given cool bar to have the highest precedence when it comes to positioning in the slot.
member.param: The given cool bar to move to the end of the slot's drawing order.

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.ToolBox.CoolBarSlot.RecalcSize
member.summary: Recalculates the size of the slot's contents.

member.summary: This resizes and redraws the contents of the slot.

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.ToolBox.CoolBarSlot.ResizeContent(System.Drawing.Rectangle)
member.summary: Resizes the slot's contents to a given size.

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.ToolBox.CoolBarSlot.InsertRectangle(Dundas.Charting.WinControl.ToolBox.CoolBar,System.Drawing.Rectangle,Dundas.Charting.WinControl.ToolBox.CoolBarRectangleCollection@)
member.summary: Inserts a cool bar with a given rectangle into the collection of already-calculated rectangles.
member.remarks:
This is the logic for layout of bars in the slot. The logic is set so later rectangles have more precedence over earlier rectangles.
As rectangles are added to the collection, existing bars are pushed outward and care is taken to make sure all the bars are on screen, but if not, they are pushed off to the right.
TODO : add the logic to handle chevrons.
member.param: The bar to add to the collection.
The desired rectangle for the bar.
The collection of already-calculated bar/rectangle pairs.

member.summary: This class represents the user interface of a cool bar button item.
member.remarks:
This is the control inside a item, and is the user interface representation of the button.
A cool bar button can have a button, drop button or drop down style.

member.name: F:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.ToolBox.CoolBarButtonControl.ButtonPaddingHeight
member.summary: The button's padding height (i.e. the vertical distance from the border to the image and/or text). Measured in pixels.

member.summary: The button's spacing between the image and the text. Measured in pixels.

member.summary: The button spacing between the drop button image and the separator line. Measured in pixels.

member.name: T:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.SmartLabels
member.summary: SmartLabels class implements the SmartLabels algorithm for the data series points. It keeps track of all labels drawn and detects their collisions. When labels collision is detected the algorithm tries to resolve it by repositioning the labels. If label can not be repositioned it maybe hidden depending on the current settings.

member.summary: This class is used for calculations of technical analyses volume indicators.

member.summary: Default Constructor

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Formulas.VolumeIndicators.MoneyFlow(System.Double[][],System.Double[][]@,System.String[],System.String[])
member.summary: The Money Flow Index ("MFI") is a momentum indicator that measures the strength of money flowing in and out of a security. It is related to the Relative Strength Index, but where the RSI only incorporates prices, the Money Flow Index accounts for volume. --------------------------------------------------------- Input: - 4 Y values ( High, Low, Close, Volume ). Output: - 1 Y value Money Flow Indicator. Parameters: - Period Extra Parameters: -

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Formulas.VolumeIndicators.PriceVolumeTrend(System.Double[][],System.Double[][]@,System.String[],System.String[])
member.summary: The Price and Volume Trend ("PVT") is similar to On Balance Volume ("OBV,") in that it is a cumulative total of volume that is adjusted depending on changes in closing prices. But where OBV adds all volume on days when prices close higher and subtracts all volume on days when prices close lower, the PVT adds/subtracts only a portion of the daily volume. The amount of volume added to the PVT is determined by the amount that prices rose or fell relative to the previous day’s close. The PVT is calculated by multiplying the day’s volume by the percent that the security’s price changed, and adding this value to a cumulative total. --------------------------------------------------------- Input: - 2 Y values ( Close, Volume ). Output: - 1 Y value Price Volume Trend Indicator. Parameters: - Extra Parameters: -

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Formulas.VolumeIndicators.OnBalanceVolume(System.Double[][],System.Double[][]@,System.String[],System.String[])
member.summary: On Balance Volume ("OBV") is a momentum indicator that relates volume to price change. OBV is one of the most popular volume indicators and was developed by Joseph Granville. Constructing an OBV line is very simple: The total volume for each day is assigned a positive or negative value depending on whether prices closed higher or lower that day. A higher close results in the volume for that day to get a positive value, while a lower close results in negative value. A running total is kept by adding or subtracting each day's volume based on the direction of the close. The direction of the OBV line is the thing to watch, not the actual volume numbers. --------------------------------------------------------- Input: - 2 Y values ( Close, Volume ). Output: - 1 Y value On Balance Volume Indicator. Parameters: - Extra Parameters: -

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Formulas.VolumeIndicators.NegativeVolumeIndex(System.Double[][],System.Double[][]@,System.String[],System.String[])
member.summary: The Negative Volume Index ("NVI") focuses on days where the volume decreases from the previous day. The premise being that the "smart money" takes positions on days when volume decreases. --------------------------------------------------------- Input: - 2 Y values ( Close, Volume ). Output: - 1 Y value Negative Volume index. Parameters: - StartValue : double Extra Parameters: -

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Formulas.VolumeIndicators.PositiveVolumeIndex(System.Double[][],System.Double[][]@,System.String[],System.String[])
member.summary: The Positive Volume Index ("PVI") focuses on days where the volume increased from the previous day. The premise being that the "crowd" takes positions on days when volume increases. Interpretation of the PVI assumes that on days when volume increases, the crowd-following "uninformed" investors are in the market. Conversely, on days with decreased volume, the "smart money" is quietly taking positions. Thus, the PVI displays what the not-so-smart-money is doing. (The Negative Volume Index, displays what the smart money is doing.) Note, however, that the PVI is not a contrarian indicator. Even though the PVI is supposed to show what the not-so-smart-money is doing, it still trends in the same direction as prices. --------------------------------------------------------- Input: - 2 Y values ( Close, Volume ). Output: - 1 Y value On Positive Volume index. Parameters: - StartValue : double Extra Parameters: -

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.Formulas.VolumeIndicators.AccumulationDistribution(System.Double[][],System.Double[][]@,System.String[],System.String[])
member.summary: The Accumulation/Distribution is a momentum indicator that associates changes in price and volume. The indicator is based on the premise that the more volume that accompanies a price move, the more significant the price move. A portion of each day’s volume is added or subtracted from a cumulative total. The nearer the closing price is to the high for the day, the more volume added to the cumulative total. The nearer the closing price is to the low for the day, the more volume subtracted from the cumulative total. If the close is exactly between the high and low prices, nothing is added to the cumulative total. --------------------------------------------------------- Input: - 4 Y values ( Hi, Low, Close, Volume ). Output: - 1 Y value Accumulation Distribution Parameters: - Extra Parameters: -

member.summary: AnnotationCollection is a class that stores chart annotation objects.
member.remarks:
All chart annotations are stored in this collection, and it is exposed as the property of the chart. It's also used to store annotations inside the class.
Methods for adding, inserting, iterating and removing annotations from the collection are available.

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.ToolBox.CoolMenuOrganizer.AttachMenu(System.Windows.Forms.Menu)
member.summary: Attaches a specified Menu object to the organizer (includes the menu's descendants).
member.remarks:
The attached menu's descendant objects will be automatically converted to the ownerdraw state and drawn in a specific way.
The reference to the attached menu is saved in an internal list object.
To not include menu descendants use the definition that has an includeDescendants parameter.

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.ToolBox.CoolMenuOrganizer.AttachMenu(System.Windows.Forms.Menu,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Attaches a specified Menu object to the organizer, and optionally includes the menu's descendants.
member.param: Determines if descendant menus are included.
member.remarks:
The attached menu's descendant objects are converted to the ownerdraw state and drawn in a specific way.
The reference to the attached menu is saved in an internal list object.

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.ToolBox.CoolMenuOrganizer.DetachMenu(System.Windows.Forms.Menu)
member.summary: Detaches the specified Menu object from the organizer (includes the menu's descendants).
member.remarks:
The attached menu's descendant objects are automatically reverted back to their original state.
To not include menu descendants use the definition that has an includeDescendants parameter.

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.ToolBox.CoolMenuOrganizer.DetachMenu(System.Windows.Forms.Menu,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Detaches the specified Menu object from the organizer, and optionally detaches the menu's descendants.
member.param: If true the descendant menus will also be detached.
member.remarks:
The attached menu's descendant objects are reverted back to their original state if
is true.

member.name: T:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.ChartUI
member.summary:
The ChartUI represents the Chart User Interface Manager.
The Chart User Interface Manager provides the most common actions required by an end-user, such as switching from 2D/3D, color change, rotation and show/hide items like legends and grid. The major components which contain the ChartUI class are , and .
The Chart User Interface is active in Dundas Chart for Windows Froms and Internet SmartClient

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.ChartUI.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Dispose(bool disposing) executes in two distinct scenarios. If disposing equals true, the method has been called directly or indirectly by a user's code. Managed and unmanaged resources can be disposed. If disposing equals false, the method has been called by the runtime from inside the finalizer and you should not reference other objects. Only unmanaged resources can be disposed.
member.param: If disposing equals true, the method has been called directly or indirectly by a user's code.

member.name: M:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.PolylineAnnotation.EndPlacement
member.summary: Ends user placement of the annotation.
member.remarks:
Ends annotation placement previously started by a method call.
This method is usually not required, since placement will automatically end when an end-user enters all required points. It is usefull when annotation placement should be aborted, for whatever reason.

member.name: P:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.PolylineAnnotation.FreeDrawPlacement
member.summary: Gets or sets a flag that determines the free-draw placement mode for an annotation.
member.value: True if the annotation should be placed using free draw mode, false otherwise. Defaults to false.
member.remarks: This annotation supports two different placement modes when the Annotation.BeginPlacement method is called. Set this property to true to switch from the default mode to free draw mode, where an end-user can free draw while moving the mouse cursor.

member.name: P:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.PolylineAnnotation.Path
member.summary: Gets or sets the path points of the polyline at run-time.
member.value: A object with the polyline shape.
member.remarks:
A polyline must use coordinates relative to the annotation object, where 0,0 is the top-left coordinate and 100,100 is the bottom-right coordinate of the annotation.
This property is not accessible at design time (at design-time use the property instead).

member.name: P:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.PolylineAnnotation.PathPoints
member.summary: Gets or sets the path points of the polyline at design-time.
member.value: An object with the polyline shape.
member.remarks:
A polyline must use coordinates relative to the annotation object, where 0,0 is the top-left coordinate and 100,100 is the bottom-right coordinate of the annotation.
This property is not accessible at run time (at run-time use the property instead).

member.name: T:Dundas.Charting.WinControl.AnnotationPathPointCollection
member.summary: AnnotationPathPointCollection is a collection of polyline annotation path points, and is only available via the PathPoints property at design-time.
member.remarks:
This collection is used AT DESIGN-TIME ONLY, and uses serialization to expose the shape of the polyline and polygon via their PathPoints colelction property.
At run-time use Path property to set the path of a polyline or polygon
